DIV1.P: THE CONQUEST OF CANADA: OR, THE SIEGE OF QUEBEC.
AN HISTORICAL TRAGEDY, OF FIVE ACTS.
BY GEORGE COCKINGS, AUTHOR OF WAR: AN HEROIC POEM.
ALBANY: PRINTED by ALEXANDER and JAMES ROBERT∣SON, at their PRINTING OFFICE in PEARL-STREET. M,DCC,LXXIII.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE PUBLIC.
DIV1.P: ALTHOUGH the undertaking is great and aru∣ous. for a person in my situation of life assit∣ed, to dare attempt th sole cmosiion of a Tragedy; yet I was incited to the ask, by ruminating on a ra∣pid, and almst uninerupted series of success, in 159. and the great and ever memorable year of 158, &c. the glorious ffect of the amicable and happy u∣nin, which subsited between our gallant troops, and intrepid ars; who▪ with a true spirit of martial brave∣ry and emulation (never to be oudone, or equalled a∣gin, but by themselves) baed, bore down. and tri∣umphed over all hostile opposition, in every quarter of the glob, both by land and sa, which the united power and policy of France, Spain, and their civilized and barbarous friends and allies, could possily exert.

At first▪ I thought to have made one entire Drama∣tic Piece of it, through the whole course of the war, so gloriously successfl to Great Britain, beyond all parallel; rendering her terrible to the nation around, and so efftually humbling to France; to ally destroy∣ing her trade▪ , and overcoming all her arma∣ments, both by land and sea; that at length she could be scarcely said to make any effort▪ deserving the name of resistance. Had I proceeded according to the above design. I then intended to have named the piece, The Muchless Aea. But whn I came to reflect upon the transaction in North America; the great and hazardous siege of Quebec, seemed to stand foremost, and claim my chief attention: For there, near 1200 veteran French, joined by Canadians, and many savage tribes,
lay intrenched at the only spot attackable; command∣ed by a bold, experienced, enterprising, (and hiter∣to) fortunate General, Monsieur de Montcalm, and many other gallant leaders, with all the advantages of art and nature on their side, to render their situation as formidable as possible, to the most intrepid foe: Yet about 8000 of Britannia's troops, assisted by her match∣less ars, lead and animated by Wolfe, Saunders, Monckton, Townshend, Holmes, Howe, Murray, Fraser, and many other leaders brave, laid siege to that strong and important fortess and capital; carried on their several attacks, with the loss of about 3000 kill∣ed and wounded; and at last, on the famed height of Abraham, with about 5000 men, gained a complete victory, and chased in a total rout, to the garrison walls, French, Indians, and Canadians! The glorious con∣sequence of which was, the surender of the city and garrison of Qebec; and soon after all Canada sub∣mitted to the victorious troops of Great-Britain. So great, and many, were the remarkable transactions of that sige, and so much worth, and bravery, was there diplayed, I hought there needed no additional aid of well wrought fiction, or fulsome adulation, to render it worthy o a dramatic representaion. I therefore re∣solved to send it oth into the world, dressed in the amiable gab of impartial vrity, under the title of The Conquest of Canada▪ Or, The iege of Quebc; and dsiged to adhere strictly to historical facts, as much as a dramatic performance would allow. Not being conversant with the stage, and consequently not well acquainted with the rules of the drama, as a dramatic writer, perhap I may have greatly erred in the com∣psitin of the play, as to time, place, circumstances, and many other minute particulars, which the most ju∣dcious and nice critics in ancient literature, may think a work of this kind deseves. But I write an historical traedy; and as a historian, have endeavoured to dis∣pla, in the different scenes, a representation of real
and genuine fact, great in themselves, as any in our times, and amply worthy of being registered in the annals of fame, as rival actions of those patriotic deeds, of the so much admired anciet Greeks and Romans! We read with pleasure and admiration the siee of Calais, Aquileia, Addison's Cato and the gallant de∣fence of the Thermopylaean pass; where the regal pa∣trit Leonidas, with his few chosen, and ever renown∣ed Spartans, Thebans, and Thespians, nobly fell, in the defence of their country, its privieges and laws. Yet at these places, nn but Gauls, Greeks, and Ro∣mans, were the worthy warriors, with whom we are so pleased. Whilst Greece and Rome boast their patrio∣tic warriors slain in defence of their laws and liberties, and France trumpets forth the noble and praise∣worthy resolutions of her Burghers at Calais, who on∣ly offered themselves at the mercy of the British royal victor, to save their country men, friends, and relatons from ruin; yet providentially escped the threatened fate, and lived very justly revered by their grateful country.

I SAY, whilst all these states seem emulously to vie with each other for the greatest honour in the records of patriotism, shall we be mute, nor give deserved ap∣pluse to these gallant country men of ours, who to save wives, children, lands and laws, fought, bled, and died in the glorious cause of freedom, and the service of their country, at Louisbourg, Quebec, &c. and shall we not enjoy a more exquisite pleasure, when we read the scenes which display the victorious intrepidity, warlike worth, or glrious deaths, not of Greeks, Gauls, and Romans, (as of has happened, against rude, babarous, or ffemined troops▪ or at best if disciplin∣ed, not trained and amed like themselves, for offen∣sie and defensive war;) but of Englishmen, Caledo∣nians▪ and Hibernians, who engaged against superior numbers, like themselves civilized; who had a con∣stant supply from large magazines of all the destruc∣tive
implements of death; trained, armed, and equal∣ly disciplined in the art of war, and well skilled in e∣very maoeuvre of the field; and were immured in strong fortesses, or advantageously intrenched; yet these they wuld often attack, and fird by pariotic ardor▪ (with an impetuosiy not to be withstood) would out from trench to rnch, chase from field t field; and drive from garrison to garrison, thee more nume∣rous, well disciplined, and veten forces, till all re∣treat was cut off, and submission became the only re∣source they had left for safety: Whilst the nations around trembled at Britannia's name, and dreaded the uited thunder-storm of her terene and naval war∣riors.

Sedately warm'd, and most Serenely bold,
(As if their presence victory insur'd)
With Britain's troops, plung'd into the flood, to
Ravish mighty fate! to bid destruction
Defiance! and outface the grim king of terrors!

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: There England's troops and tars were nobly try'd;

SP.L: 'Twas high time to give it up; else Hardy,
And Bocawen, wou'd soon have made the place
Too hot for him, and from their double tiers
Have sent him such a surly summons, as
Would have puzzled him, and nonplus'd all his
Troops e'er they could recollect themselves, to
Remit them a reply of equal weight.
But my worthy friend, you forgot, or else
Omitted one great transaction of the
Siege; the ships, the ships, the boats took.

SP.SPEAKER: Land Off.
SP.L: Right: I had forgot indeed:
One night the fleet's boats, under the command
Of the bold Balour, and Laforey, row'd
Into the harbour of Louisbourg, and
Amidst all the terrors of a gloomy night,
In an unfriendly port, thro' a random
Strom of death, and under cover of their
Garrison, they bravely boarded, and took
Possession of two men of war at once,
A sixty, and a seventy four gun ship!
They burnt Le Prudent, (which stuck a ground,)
And from the harbour tow'd Le Benaant
Away!

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.P: We generally go through with what we Take in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Land Off
SP.L: A few words more before we part.
I wonder what posse'd the French nation
T kindle up aresh the flames of war,
Or after kindling them, stll to carry
On the war, whilst Old England own'd a Pitt;
And for their terror on the land, a Wolfe,
An Amherst, and a Granby, a Johnson,
Williams, Foy Phillips, Drummond, and Macbean;
A Frzer, Olive, Cooe, a Townshend, Elliot,
And a Murray: Wth such a num'rous list
Besides of worthies, in the triple union
Of England, that when all fam'd Homer's boasted
Warriors are compar'd with them, they seem a
Few, each of them an equal to Hector,
And a rival to fierce Mars.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: And for their scourge at sea, a Hawke, a Howe,
A Saunders, a Pocock, and Boscawen;
A Gilchrist, Clements, Elliot, and Logie;
A Kppel, Rodney, Lockhart, Tyrrel, Forrest;
A Hardy, Holmes, a Langdon, and a Suckling:
With hundred more▪ all hardy tars and good
Commanders brave, each of whose names wou'd sound
In a Frenchman's ears, like to a clap of Thunder!
[Going Off.] We've whole fleets mann'd with brave fellows. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Land Off.
SP.P: [Going Off.] Whole reg'ments of heroes!

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Come on my brave tars! let's away to the wars,
To the siege of Quebec let's advance;
Our anchor's a trip, et's away to the ship,
And bellow defiance to France.
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: We'll spread ev'ry sail, with a prosperous gale,
Thro' the kingdom of Neptune we'll roam!
If we meet the ench fleet, in thunder we'll greet,
Well take 'em, or drive them all home.
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: If they dare to engage, and meet British rage,
We'll bear closely down to the fight;
Yard arm and yard arm, their jackets well warm,
For that is the Britons delight.
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: When the fight is begun, lest away they shou'd run,
Our grapples shall hold us together;
'Tis a sport they don't like, we'll soon make'em strike,
And straightway bear down to another.
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Well range to 'em close, and a terrible dose,
For a sample, we'll send the Monsieurs;
If the fight does not end, then another we'll send,
From both of our thundering tiers!
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: On their quarters we'll board, with pike, pistols and sword;
Hawke like we will pounce on our prey;
We'll make them our own, and their flags we'll haul down,
For George shall be Sovereign at sea.
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: When our thunder shall break, o'er the walls of Quebec,
Monsieurs! your strong ramparts shan't save ye;
Your heads shall all droop! and your walls shall all stoop!
When shook by the sons of the navy!
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: Tho' your tow'rs should arise, o'er the clouds in the skies,
Let Saunders but say that we must
Pluck 'em up to the base, each fortress we'll raze,
And trample your pride in the dust!
Brave boys, &c.

LG.HEAD: IX
LG.L: When we shall unite, with our troops in the fight▪
And emulous jealousy calls,
As hurricanes sweep thro' the land and the deep.
Well sweep to destruction the Gauls! Brave boys. &c.
Exeunt omnes, huzzang.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonatus.

Their troops ours by far. Strong are

SP.SPEAKER: Britannicus.

DIV3.STAGE: MONTMORENCI; (MONTCALM's Camp.) MONT∣CALM, LEVI, and BOUGAINVILLE, in a Tent.

SP.SPEAKER: BOUGAINVILLE to MONTCALM.
SP.L: So it seems Sir, the Britons demanded
The town and garrison of Quebec, and
Have sent three young Gen'rals with eight thousand
Troops on the sleeveless errand?

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Being this day, with some others, at the
Governor's conven'd, I hear'd the British
Officer when he made the proud demand,
Which we rejected with disdain, and sent
Him back with such a message to their camp,
As will give their enterprising boasted
Wolfe, but little pleasure.
On our refusal, he denounc'd rough war,
And threaten'd devestation to the town
And garrison:—
And by a prisoner we have taken,
We learn that they intend shortly to storm
Us in our trenches.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.
SP.L: These Britons wou'd be thought in∣vincible,
And dream of nothing else but asking for
Our forts, our towns and garrisons, as if
The mention of their names had a magic
Charm in it! wou'd waste our troops! and batte
Down our walls! but they're mistaken!
Whene'er they land at Montmorenci, let
Us from our trenches pour down upon them,
And shouting loud as Niagara's steep
Cataract, with th' like rapidity,
Bear all down before us! leave the straggling
Offals of destruction, as delicious
Morsels for our savages! and scourge the
Insolence of their young leaders!

SP.SPEAKER: Montclam.
SP.L: Be not too rash, good Sir.
We must not give them battle on the plain,
Nor carry on offensive war:
Tho' young their leaders, and their troops but few,
Their Monarch, and their Minister, are too
Sgacious to be deceived in this so
Critical a choice! (no Pompadour rules there.)
Whate'er their years, and muster roll, are found
Deficient in, depend upon it, 'tis
Over ballanc'd well, by intrepidity
Of soul! active resolution! a firm
Contempt of danger! and well try'd vet'ran
Service!

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: Lead we not better troops than they?
Besides, our numbers, bating savages,
Are full four thousand more; we've every male
Inhabitant within the town to back
Us, they are some thousands; why shou'd we then
Within our trenches sculk, as if afraid
To meet them in the open field? rather
Let us run them down by numbers! and as
The lordly lion serves the foremost hunters.
When they press upon him, sprn them to a
Knowledge of themselves! who fancy now they
ise superior to the common rank of
en! or else let us make them in a forc'd
treat, precipitate themselves into
e sea!

SP.L: Rather than dream of driving them before
like a tim'rous flock of sheep, let us
pare to stand their furious charge, when they
e rav'nous wolves, o'erleaping shp-folds, shall
unt our breast-works; and plunge into our treach!
ich if they shou'd, they will not fail to make
feel their mortal gripe!
I repose but little confidence

Quebec, and less in our savage

SP.L: Pardon me, Monsieur;

midst the forig surges on the
choosig death, amidst the fire
O thousands there intrench'd! rather than be

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.

forces at present, come against
Quebec?

SP.L: To put us serious on our guards.

Such rage! no obstacle

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: All this is grated, Sir▪
But the case at present chang'd:
At Louisbourg, they had twice their present
, and then we sent not all our troops
To their descent; but if we now
our savage friends, we number twice
; our twelve thousand regula are
Veteran French, and have been often try'd
Th the continent; we, ourselves, have seen
Each other try'd in bottle; why shou'd we

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm
SP.L: That my resolve, and arguments, do not

oselves appeal.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Hear me then with patience.
That we, I think, will stand the test, is put

Thousands more than they; but our success must
Be the chell hinge, on which the affairs of
must turn: This barrier pass'd,
They'll sweep onward like an inundation!
And overwhelm each Gallie settlement
in undistinguish'd ruin! and as the
Event of war was ever dubious, and
Numbers have not always conquer'd Englishmen;
Why shou'd we give them equal battle, and
Throw all at stake upon th' uncertain chance?

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: I see no need to fear the coming to a battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.
SP.L: Nor can I doubt of matching them, whom hand
To hand engag'd: Eight thousand may begin

Impetuous charge; shou'd these be repell'd,
A corps de reserve of four thousand men,

Help them to rally, and with new spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Our bus'ness here is to preserve Quebec▪

And our royal fleets, therefore we can have
But little hope of a supply of men
From France: As for our invading foes, all
Their attacks must be with loss attended:
They're few already, and their troops will thin:
Perhaps being harrass'd, sickness may ensue,
And they'll grow weary of the tardy siege:
Then, when their spirits shall be most depress'd,
Rush we'll on them with our united force:
Beat up their sickly camp! and make them take
A bloody farwell! by which means, we shall
Preserve our troops, our honours and Quebec.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.
SP.L: On cool reflection, I now see pla

SP.SPEAKER: Levi to Montcalm.
SP.L: To your superior judgment I sub∣mit,
And well applaud the plan of operation.
This method may perhaps be better than
Fitch'd battles, where one chance blow, a signal
Misapply'd, or word misunderstood,
May turn the sway of action, subvert the
Best concerted schemes, and fling a conquest
Into the arms of those, who waited but
The signal to desert the field: And all
The world allows, that warlike arts and skill
Mature, (with policy apply'd) to save
The men, and gain the cheapest victories,
(If not the first qualifications, they
Are) to personal bravery, the next
Best requisite in any General.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville. to Montcalm.
SP.L: I've nothing to object Sir,
To your opinion I'm entirely won.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Be it our chiefest care then to protract
The siege, and save our men: Behind us lies
Montreal, against which place, I learn the
Gallant and experienc'd Amherst, their

Fierce Wolfe, no doubt, intends a junction; but
In all human probability, they
Never can surmount each obstacle, and
Soon enough arrive with their expected
Aid: But shou'd that reinforcement come, the
Less our present loss, and harrassment now
Is, the better we shall then receive them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville
SP.L: Let us dam up th' entrance into Quebec;

Well, and render innaccessable, as
Art, and warlike terrors can.—
In these Northern climes, the winter will come
On apace, and frustrate ev'ry hostile
Plan; their thin remains the (baffled refuse
Of repeated skirmishes) will then return
With disappointed hopes and sullen shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: But when they land let us be well prepar'd
For their reception; for they'll compel us
To believe their leaders fierce! and all their
Forces brave! Exeunt omnes.

And bring them all to bear upon the fire ship!
Carpenters! stand by to cut the cables!

SP.SPEAKER: Second Off.
SP.L: Pull up your starboard oars briskly my lads!
And keep her well to starboard of us:
Take care; don't fall athwart the ship's hawse
Astern of us.

STAGE.HI: Sailors bl out, Whurrow, whurrow: Never fear, never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Second Off.
SP.L: She goes clear of us:
They have her under command.

STAGE.HI: Inner Trumpet, Lieutenant Hatchway, Front Trumpet, ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Inner Trumpet.
SP.L: I can perceive no more fire floats and fire ships
Coming; that whole division may be employ'd
In picking up such as pass'd the Point.

SP.SPEAKER: Front Trumpet.
SP.L: They are all clapp'd on board by this time,
And greatest part of them landed on Terra Firma:
The most mischief they've done us, was just
To singe one of the ships sides as they pass'd.
SP.STAGE: All the sailors within, Huzza! huzza! huzza! scene closes; lights descend.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: POINT LEVI: Centinels call in this manner behind the scenes, going up the right side thrice; that is in the front, center, and rear▪ All's well: The like on the left side, rear, center and front, all's well: At a distance, as on eard the fleet in the river, all's well; all's well; all's well; all's well; different voices.
WOLFE Solus, in his Tent.
DIV3.L: The dreadful tumult of this horrid night
Is o'er, and with its clamours are all its
Terrors vanish'd.
Stuck frm upon the shore, in harmless blaze,
These engines of destruction melt away.
Throughout the fleet the voice of safety runs▪
And thro' the camp, from right to left, I hear
The centinels revolve the welcome sound.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter a SEA OFFICER. WOLFE to him,
DIV3.L: I congratulate you, Sir, on this night's
Success, and the safety of all our fleet.
We have luckily escap'd the danger,
With which thse fire ships threaten'd us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: They threaten'd us with no less than total
in relentless blaze! it was
A of policy, and the
French had like to have rais'd the siege at one
Decisive blo. We had warm and busy
Duty, and ev'ry boat belonging to
The fleet, was well employ'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: Upon this point, wrapp'd in suspense I stood,
To see the fiery luge oling down
Upon us, nor stir'd from hence, until each
Flame was tow'd on shore, nor fail'd to mark with
Pleasure, the transactions of the boats, and
The activity of our ars.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: They all behav'd worthy of the fame they
Have 'midst fire and smoke, in naval battles
Gain'd: when first th' alarm was giv'n to mann our
Boats, to meet and stop the fire ships, and floats,
Turn'd adrift upon the stream towards us▪
They ne'er betray'd one token of base fear,
Or backward tardiness for duty, tho'
All a head appear'd, as if the fiery
Phlegethon had risen from its burning
Bed, and from the hostile walls, was pouring
Down it's sulph'rous torrent upon our fleet:
With all the speed that oar's cou'd make, they row'd
Amidst the gloomy danger, surrounded
On each side by floating flame! and as they
Breath'd drew in thick clouds of suffocating smoke:
Still, as fresh ships and fire floats, came pouring
Down, new spirits and new strength they seem'd to
Gain! with busy anxious minds they boldly
Wrought, and clear from ev'ry ship they tow'd
Th' internal flame!

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: Whilst they were busy in the burning war,
We in a vigilant suspense remain'd
For battle ready, we might repel the
Sudden onset expected from the French;
'Twas there they fail'd in policy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: Perhaps in courage, Sir: 'tis seldom known
They beat up English camps, or board a ship,
Except when they are greatly superior
In their force and numbers, and have a most
Convenient opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: England, I think is most peculiarly
Happy in her naval powers; I see
No cause to doubt their future conduct in
This siege; we have here, brave, vigilant, and
Hardy officers and seamen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: Their match in all his annual round the
Sun sees not, so capable of duty,
Or so agile in the working of the
Ship, and brimful of alacrity, when
Bearing down upon the foe to to battle.
On the mortal verge of close engagement▪
I've seen their souls o'erflow with joy! and their
Full charg'd hearts, like rivers rising o'er their
Bank, pour out a flood of rough but apt and
Daring sentiments!
England exult! tell wond'ring nations round,
Thy freeborn tars mock at the name of fear!
Fear not my lad says ev'ry British tar,
And plunges thro' the thunder of fight!
Where lame and death, and war, rage in the most
Tumultuous manner, there shout Britannia's
Seamen, and with delight engage!

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: I hope they'll still deserve the name they've gain'd,
And live in friendly union with our troops:
To morrow I intend another rough
Trial of their bvery and spirit,
When they shall launch our sons of Mars upon the shore.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: I'll pawn my life our sailors will not fail,
I bid you, Sir, good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.P: The same to you, Sir. Exit Officer.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe solus.
SP.L: O thou, whose never sleeping eyes pierce at
One ance thro' space immense, wtch o'er our camp!
Retard all hostile ills! and shield us from surprise!

DIV3.STAGE: Exit Wolfe, or the scene closes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: The French Camp at MONTORENCI, MONTCALM. and BOUGAINVILLE.

SP.SPEAKER: MONTCALM.
SP.L: Our grand scheme is baffled, and all our hopes
From that quarter are frustrated.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.
SP.L: I had such a firm reliance on it,
I thought it would surpass all human pow'r
To baffle it: I expected no less
Than universal ruin to their fleet,
To have seen their powder blaze, and all their
Stores expire in flames, whilst from their ships they
Leapt by hundreds, and plung'd to watry death
Below, t'escape the burning war above:
At least, I thought the greedy flame wou'd have
Devour'd sev'ral ships, and forc'd some others
On the shore, and some whole crews have perish'd
In the wild confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: But see how contrary last night's event!
Their sailors seem another race of men,
Whene'er compar'd 'gainst other countries tars,
And like the water, sulpher, smoke and flame!
Seem almost to be their element! they
Laugh at threat'ning danger! and play with black
Destruction!

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.
SP.L: They've done this night, what England may ever
Boast, what France will scarce believe, and other
Nations stand astonish'd at!

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Ungrateful truth! How many of us from
Our diff'rent posts, mark'd with what unconcern,
And chearful resolution, they met the
Flaming fleet! Oars mix'd with oars, like persons
Striving for the goal! the sternmost drove the
Head most on! cheering each other with their
Nise! all full of emulation, who shou'd
Throw the grapples first! and thronging fiercely
To catch each flame, they form'd (if I may use
The expessn) a sort of nval phaanx,
for any of our fire floats to
Pass, and do the wish'd fo executio!
For the future, but from the like
We can : they are so warn'd, and will
Not now be off their guard. Besides, it was
The chiest effort we can make, and they
Who baled this, will see at all our vain attempts.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm
SP.L: Next we may expect to meet them on the
Sre; for flush'd wih this success, and full of
Indignation the great design, no
Doubt they'll make some desperate push, by way of
Pierce retaliation.— Let u expect
The worst, 'twill rouse us more! and if we can
Repel them now, perhaps they'll raise the siege.

SP.SPEAKER: Bougainville.
SP.L: Let them come on!—we fear them not!
We're ready!—They shall have a warm Welcome!

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: And such I hope, as will prevent their bold
Intrusion for the future. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A NUNNERY, a LADY ABBESS, and TWO NUNS.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY ABBESS,
SP.L: OH how welcome seems the returning day,
After this night of horrors!—

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Nun.
SP.L: [crssing herelf] Blessed Mary defend us, from all the
Threat'ning dangers of the succeeding night!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Nun.
SP.L: [crossing herself] May all the holy angels, and host of
Saints, be our protection this day; and the
Ensing days, until our army drives
The enemies away.
Heav'nly Father!— [crossing herself.]
Such another night, for all the world I
not choose to pass!—
And the of our own guns
In he garrison▪ (so near us) and the
Continual discharge from Point Levi, and
The Briish shps▪ of mortars and cannon,
The city seem'd to rel▪ nay, the very
Gound trembled under us! whilst the whole ai
one uninermitted shock; and in
undting space, long hung the hoarse
sound▪ like distant thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Nun.
SP.L: Good heav'n!—
was the scene within our walls!
he cheering company of the
intrepi sex, to sooth our souls and
Calm our eart▪ each siter gave herself for lost!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Nun
SP.L: How shocking thro' the gloom of night, woud the
Dicharge of their artil'ry, and mortars,
like lighning, against our walls, and gleam
thro' the long range of all our
and then to raise us from the trembling
Spor into Which the sight had thrown us,
Instantly, the trrific roar roll'd over head!

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Nun.
SP.L: Methinks I yet hear the battering of
Te balls! and see the shells▪ (like meteors)
With their flaming tails▪ descending thro' the air!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Abbess.
SP.L: The shrieking sisterhood, (like a flock of
Fghtn'd doves, trembling! and scat'ring from an
Eagle sng down) oft as they hear'd the
Vice; a shell! or flight of shells! in
Dleful accents pierce their ears▪ or saw the
ming show'r aloft▪ fell prostrate! kneel'd! and
Pray'd! or ran almost each a different
Way, as fear suggested; seeking shelter,
And dubious of the event!—and from our
Apartments, as they burst around us, broke
Forth a terrifying scream!—

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Nun.
SP.L: To this without our walls, in a dismal
Concert, rung the groans, and cries, of dying
People!—Houses tumbling into ruins!—
Or perishing in flames:—Fearful mothers,
With their children crying, and thronging in
Heaps; not knowing where to fly for present
Security, and calling loud on all
The saints for help.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Abbess.
SP.L: Alas! in vain!—
For over head would rise another show'r
Of shells, and send them screeching headlong to
A distant spot!—many too slowly fled;
For death, with unrelenting hast, follow'd
At their heels, and as a peasant cuts thro'
A grassy meadow, so he mow'd down the
Crowd!—

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Nun.
SP.L: Oh terrible!—if they shou'd take the City
And we shou'd fall into the hands of these
Rough Englishmen!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Nun.
SP.P: I'm shock'd at the thought!—

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Nun.
SP.L: The very idea harrows up my
Soul!—
And darts a tremor thro' every nerve!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Abbess.
SP.L: I hope it will not happen as you fear,
We have all the saints on our sides, to pray
For us: the bold General Montcalm, (who
Has often beat them) and twelve thousand French
Solders, with a Canadian militia,
And some thousands of Indians, to fight for
Us, and they are not half our number.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Nun.
SP.L: But still my good Lady they may beat us;
And then alas what may we expect will
Be the consequence!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Nun. to Lady Abbess.
SP.L: Our Confessors, Father Dominic, and
Father Francis, have told us strange things.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Abbess.
SP.L: Perhaps our good Fathers were a little
Too rash in forming their judgments, or were
Misinform'd. What their whole nation is, I
Cannot say; but I'm told by a Lady,
Who was at Louibourg when taken by them,
That the officers behaved with the greatest
Civility and politeness to all,
But in a more peculiar manner, to
The religious Ladies, and orders, of
All sorts; kept the strictest decorum in
The town, among their soldiers, and stuck most
Honourably to their capitulation,
Injuring none, after the deliv'ry
Of the forts and town.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Nun to Lady Abbess.
SP.L: I'm greatly shock'd at what our Confessors
Have told us!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Abbess.
SP.L: My dear children, discard these fears: I hope
The Governor will not give up the town;
But if he should, let this calm all our doubts:
These are the men, who treated their captive
Enemies with so much humanity
And good manners at Louisbourg.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Nun to Lady Abbess
SP.P: How know you that, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Abbess.
SP.L: From the same Lady, who inform'd me of
Ther former behaviour. I trust we're safe
From personal insult: for where the true
Spiit of brav'ry inspires the breast of
Any Commanders in Chief, a manly
Generosity accompanies it;
they'll keep the troops under their command,
order and discipline.
Heav'n hear my pray'r and grant they may!
almost at my wits end!—
But for your further comfort, my ghostly
tells me, we are by and by to
a general solemn procession,
of Misericordia, to
the ruin which threatens us,
invasion of our enemie.
Let us retire my children, and join with
Them in their petitions for victory.
This is our last, our best resource, in all
Our dangers. Exeunt omnes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: POINT LEVI: WOLFE solus, in his Tent.
DIV3.L: The hour is near; and swift upon the wings
Of time the minute rides, pregnant with !
And full of dread decision; whether we
Rout them from their fortyfi'c entrenchments,
Or retreat with loss from Montmorenci,
The purple bed of honour will this day
Be throng'd with British worthies.
[Enter an Officer.] Sir all the forces are embark'd, the ships
Are station'd for their cover, both officers
And men are in high spirits, and all seem
To be resolutely ready to force
The Gallic lines, and make their landing good.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: The lover pining in the absence of
The fair inchantress of his heart, ne'er felt
Such a flood of joy rush in upon his
Soul, when she returning, charms his ears with
The well known accts of her tongue, a I
Now feel, to hear the welcome tale;—which tale,
Has rous'd me to the onset, and kindled
Ev'ry martial sentiment within my
Soul, I go, at honourable Freedom's
Call. To fiht my country's bale. Exeunt.

DIV3.STAGE: [Curtain falls, thunders, and a discharge of artlery, and small arms▪ drums beating, and a Curtain rises, and Capt. and Lieut. PEYTON, wounded among ; Mr. PEYTN's, being armed and a ]
Enter a SERJEANT, and some GRENADIERS as retreating.

SP.L: O! dismal sight of grief! here wounded he
Our Captain and Lieutenant!

SP.SPEAKER: Serjeant.
SP.P: We'll bear them off, tho' thousands dam the pass.
SP.STAGE: Speaking to Ochterlony, and reaching him his hand.
SP.L: Re worhy Sir, and on my back ascend;
as a miser bears his lead of pelf,
rushing from a house inwrapt in flame,
My wling shoulders shall sustain your weight;
Thro' crimson floods, and numbers of the :
Another will your good Lieutenant take;
The rest all opposition shall defy.
'Till we in safety shall depose our charge,
Rese'd from death, and far from scalping foes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ochterlony.
SP.L: My gen'rous men, I ever thought you brave,
And worthy of the same our troops have gain'd;
I feel I have my mortal wound receiv'd,
Should I retard your quick retreat, you're lost:
I am not therefore worth the hazard of
Your lives, which yet may be of service to
Your country, and in future days revenge
My fll. Here let me lie, in painful joy,
Reflecting on my soldiers proffer'd love;
bar the gallant Peyton from the field,
I know his valour, and I love the man!
Perhaps the foe may one day feel his worth,
And you his gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Soldiers.
SP.P: We'll take you likewise, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ochterlony.
SP.L: Soldiers, no more: I will not hazard lives
So precious to Great-Britain, and my king;
Nor at so great a price, will early buy
A ew short painful useless moments here:
But oh! fulfil my last my bet request!
Preserve my friend; defend his precious life;
And bear him safely hence!
SP.STAGE: Ochterlony on a dead body. Soldiers move towards Mr. Peyton.

SP.SPEAKER: Peyton.
SP.L: Stand off soldiers! nor think to take me hence.
O can! can I bear the cruciating thought!
How shall I when amongst our troops arriv'd
E'er cast a look of warm reflection back,
And in idea see my gallant friend,
My Ochterlony! whilst alive forsook!
And by his Peyton! Oh, then to see him
Drown'd in blood! by savage foes incircled,
Screaming aloud th' infernal yell of joy;
Then see the toma sink into his head:
His body mangled; and his scalp torn off,
Whilst he perhaps is vainly calling on
His absent friend!—
No Peyton near, to dart like lightning on
Them! and with remorseless amicable
Fury, tread them down among their kindred
Fiends below!

SP.SPEAKER: Serjeant.
SP.L: Consider, Sir, reject not timely aid,
Tho' fractur'd be your bone, vigor remains,
And youth, and time may give that part new strength;
Besides you yet may serve your country.

SP.SPEAKER: Peyton.
SP.L: Serjeant, thou spok'st a dagger to my heart:
For safety, and for life, my country calls,
Then who shall Ochterlony save! pausing a little.
It is resolv'd:—and here will I remain.
SP.STAGE: Speaking now in a commanding tone:
SP.L: Soldiers, with speed retreat while yet you may!

SP.SPEAKER: Serjeant.
SP.L: Farewel, ye brave and much lov'd officers;
We'd gladly bear you hence, and with our lives
At stake defend you both wou'd, you consent;
But here we can no longer safely stay,
Our duty to our country calls us hence;
For from their lofty trenches like a flood,
The Frenchmen pour o'er Montmorenci's field,
And like grim furies from th' infernal coast,
The cruel savage bands are straggling round.
SP.STAGE: [Ti Indians yell]
SP.L: Hark!
They yell the tranq which they'll soon enjoy
Amidst the scalping scene! we promise this,
Our friends once more rejoin'd, we'll rouze them to
Avenge your cause. Exeunt soldiers.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Maet OCHTERLONY and PEYTON.

SP.SPEAKER: ORCHTERLONY.
SP.L: Oh, my dear friend, e'er 'tis too late, be gone.
Peyton▪ persuade me not, for I am fixt as fate!
Watchful and fierce, as is the dragon said
To stand, and guard the bright hesperian tree;
So will I guard thee from the savage foes:
Perhaps some foe of manly sentiment,
By Providence directed, may approach;
At least, before I die, amongst the scalpers
I'll so read a gloomy scene of slaughter, and
Fall with thee amidst a glorious ruin!
SP.STAGE: An Indian yell, Ochterlony attempts to rise, Peyton begins to lead his fusee; the scene clses the mean time.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Captain MACDONALD, with a party of Highlanders, and a dead body.

SP.SPEAKER: MACDONALD.
SP.L: Yonder I see an English officer.
Towards him speeds a band of savages;
He seems design'd to stand on his defence,
Too great the odds!—
Three thither haste, and to his rescue fly!
SP.STAGE: Exeunt three Highlanders with drawn swords.
SP.L: Now onward with our fallen friend. Exeunt omnes.
SP.STAGE: Re-enter three Highlanders, with drawn swords, and Mr. Peyton on one of their shoulders, with his .

SP.SPEAKER: Peyton.
SP.L: Soldiers, I thank you for this timely rescue:
To what officer owe I this obligation?

SP.SPEAKER: First Highl.
SP.L: Capt. Macdonald, of Fraser's battalion,
Whose frown against the French nerves all our arms
With strength, and edges every sword, to hew
Him out the path to glory; he sent us:
We slew with pleasure to your aid, and flesh'd
Our steel in every scalper we could reach.
SP.STAGE: An Indian yell, they all face about, and Peyton claps his in his shoulder. The Indians halt.

SP.SPEAKER: Peyton.
SP.L: Dare not come! then bear me onward:
ambuscide nd murd
They ne'er cou'd face th' uplift steel,
Norland he light'ning of an English eye. Exeunt omnes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.STAGE: The Camp on POINT LEVI: Enter a SEA OFFICER, and a CALEDONIAN CHIEF.

SP.SPEAKER: SEA OFFICER.
SP.P: So Peyton is return'd? but Ochterlony's lost?

SP.SPEAKER: Caledon. Chief.
SP.L: That is not certain: Mr. Peyton says,
He saw him with a Frenchman, standing near
The breastwork, and therefore he has hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: Heav'n grant his hopes are true.—
But tell me Sir, what pass'd while they remain'd
Upon the field of battle?

SP.SPEAKER: Cal. Ch.
SP.L: Whilst Ochterlony's bleeding heart glow'd with
Undissembled love, (which none but friends can
Feel) and pour'd out salutary wishes
For his friend, Peyton, (like a bear growling
O'er her wounded whelp) was swallow'd up in
Friendly rage▪ and fiercely meditated
Great revenge, if any hand should rudely
Touch his Ochterlony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: Well worthy they the names of soldiers and
Of friends:—What ensu'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Cal. Ch.
SP.L: Not long they lay in pain, 'midst blood and carnage,
E'er two feil savages towards them came,
Whose cruel meins, and ireful eyes, declar'd
Their rugged souls ne'er felt a tender thought,
Join'd by a Gaul, as savage as themselves;
Thse wounded Ochterlony several times,
he unfortunately was unarm'd,
And sa no iedly weapon in his reach,
With which to deal the Cldonian blow,
And like a dying lion, fall amdt
Te slaugher of his ners!

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Of.
SP.L: On, barbarous ad inhuman! to wound
mercy, and a prisoner!—
poceed.
He of their outrage to his friend complain'd:
Qck as a spirit answers Merlin' call,
The magic sound rous'd Peyton frm the earth;
(Who in his friend's danger forgot his own:)
He frown'd in flame, and sent the leaden fate!
Death seiz'd a savage, and he groa'd his last!
His mate upon th' Hiernian quick advanc'd;
They both fi'd, both wounded were, yet both stood;
The savage flesh'd his bayet in his side;
His fractur'd leg, and loss of blood forgot,
Peyton's left hand his next thrust parry'd well,
And flung wide off the sanguin'd point! whilst from
H side his right a dagger drew, so well
The bold Hiberman play'd the steel, he sheath'd
I in his cruel heart! and spurn'd the vanquin'd
Savage to the ground!

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.P: You fil my mind with pleasing wonder!

SP.L: I tell you nought but truth; and more can add,
How French artillery on Peyton play'd,
Thund'ring applause, and roaring loud acclaim!
What further happen'd you already know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea Off.
SP.L: But think you not we made a fierce attack
Upon the French?
We did indeed—and a horrid
Scene it was!
The beowing engine of the skies began
To growl! o'er the summit of the hill a
omy horror lowr'd! and own the clouds pour'd
Their liquid torrents, and sheets of surph'rous
Flame; a prelude to that storm, which from the
French camp seen after roar'd in pond'rous showr's
Of ld! High over-head th' aethereal
Frapors broke; against our front the Gallic
Artificial thunder roll'd! on ev'ry
Se our friendly infantry, and cannon,
Help'd to make the rattling concert up!
(Celial and terrestrial lightning mix'd.)
The French artillery, and small arms, swept
Whole platoons away, and cut wide lanes of
Crnage! among the landing troops and boats,
In ming show'rs, the countless bombs came down,
And in displosion made promiscous havoc?
So that tho' floods of flame, and deluges
O: death, our men rush'd on to battle!

SP.SPEAKER: Sea. Off.
SP.L: And did like men full well acquit themselves:
As well they might, when they had such a bright
Example set by Monckton, Wolfe and Townshend,
To rose a noble emulation in
Their souls; and their diff'rent corps were headed
By many other leaders brave, old in
Renown, and well accustom'd to look death
And danger in the face.
We made the attack to let the French∣men see
We tear'd not death in any form, but might
As well have thought of plucking mountains up
the roots, as of dragging Mootcalm and
per force, against their wills, out of
subterraneous caverns, or else, to
more proper, from their lofty furrow'd
Pices of the rocks, for trench on
Tch rose, dreadfully beyond each other,
And made a terrible gradation
In the , as if they meant to sleep with
Clouds for curtains to their deep entrenchments,
And doubted the common surface of the
Glbe too low for safety.
Our Gen'rals, at the disappointment, seem
Chagin'd, but undismay'd, and wait with fierce
Impatience for an opportunity▪
To wipe the mem'ry of this foil away;
When, as the sun blazes from an eclipse,
They may rise more terrible in a storm
Of vengeance, from this disaster, run their
Gloomy courses and set in Gallic blood.
I understand, as soon as possible,
They are resolved to storm the town, or force
Them to a battle distant from their trenches.

SP.SPEAKER: Caled. Chief.
SP.L: These are the leaders for me, and these our
Country will revere.
Like the well-fed stallion in the stall, when
He scents the female, at th' alarm of war,
Their active souls grow restive; disdain the
Bounds by nature circumscrib'd, wou'd break the
Stubborn dam, and thro' the battle wing their
Way, to wed dame honour in the bloody field.
We came not here to sleep our time away,
And then return, and then tell our friends we saw
Quebec and Montcalm's camp, from Levi's Point,
Made one attempt (which, like a flash of powder,
Vanish'd into smoke) and then grew tir'd of the siege.
SP.STAGE: Looking on his watch:
SP.L: Let us be gone, our duty calls, and that
Shou'd never be neglected by a soldier,
But especially on hostile ground. Exeunt

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV3.STAGE: POINT LEVI. WOLFE, LEONATUS, BRITANNICUS and two CALEDONIAN CHIEFS, sitting in a Tent.
Wolfe, [with a letter in his hand, speaking and looking, as if partly reading the letter.]
DIV3.L: Gentlemen;
From our worthy brother Amherst comes this
Advice; that as the distance 'twixt us is
So wide, and Montreal well garrison'd,
Dams up the road thro' which he needs must march,
And with his ow'r unaided, force a pass
Thro' then etrencmen, ambcs, defiles,
And deep morrasses, most clamer rec an
Hl▪ and thro' whose forre's ew, beet with
Savage nations, and French troops▪ psses'd of
Most advantageous pots; being well assur'd,
He of necessiy must sight thro' al
The cogrgated force of Canada.
er he can effect a juctin with us;
He therefore thinks it necessary to
Inform us, 'twill be full lae before he
Comes, if he arrives at all; especially
When he considers, how necessary
His presence is, where he now remains with
All his forces: He therefore recommends
Us to the care of Providence, trusting
In the goodness of our cause, and concludes
With strong assurance, he will join us if
'Tis practicable.

SP.SPEAKER: Cal Ch.
SP.L: If Sir Jeffery Amerst cannot join
Us with those gallant troops he leads (which we
Indeed cou'd wish) let us not waste the short
L'd season in fruitless wishes, and a
Distant war, or grieve because the French by
U are not out-number'; but let us, as
Has been hinted, by some means gain
The Height of Abraham, and in Montcalm's
Sight invert their walls; no doubt' will oze the
Frenchmn to a battle; and when the shall
Advance to fight, we wl upon ourselves
Rly; and in our front shall march stern fate!
Sostain'd on either wing by gloomy terror!
Intrepidity shall head the main corps!
And bold resolution shall bring up the
Rear, and us in the stead of numbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Britann.
SP.L: Gen'ral Amherst join us not, yet he
Will be of service to us, shou'd w be
Still compell'd to carry on the Siege by
: He keeps in awe the inland
I around, and is a crub on each sort,
settlement the French have
the center of their

path, fircely waits to leap upon
, should they e'er dare attempt to join,
oureal seems terriy'd but at
Te tumour of his ear approach, from whence
We may expect they wil no force
Against us — But I'm fo speedy work, and

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Ca. Ch.
SP.L: et us strike some noble blow, and make an
Attempt wrthy of ourselves, before a
Sickness seize▪ on our camp, or sluggish
Inactivity benumbs the spirits
O our men.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonatus.
SP.L: Tho' brave and experienced the Gallic
Commanders; veteran and more num'rous
Their forces, with all the advantages
On their side, of art and nature; such are
The offices we have with us, and such
The sev'ral corps they lead, on them I
Ground my eager hopes of victory, and
to hazard all a soldier can hold
Most dear, both and hnour, on equal
ooting, in a close engagement with our
Enemies. Wolfe, &c. risng.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: Gentlemen!
I eel a mighty pleasure in my mind,
To see the forward dispositions of
Your souls, Which I oftimes in our other
Leaders have observ'd likewise, nor do the
Soldiers seem to want th' ingredient
Necessary for my plan —
This day I'll call a council, wherein I
Will propose (and doubt not but 'twill meet the
Wish'd-for approbation) that our army
Be e'er night embark'd in boats, with ev'ry
Necessary dispsition for a
Battle, which boats shall row some miles beyond
Quebec, upon the tide, and when that tide
Returns, then wrapt in silence, and the gloom
Of friendly night, we'll gently downward glide
Upon the stream, and at the foot of that
Rough precipice, whose top communicates
With Abraham's Height, we'll land unseen, and
Up the stony steep we'll climb, 'till we have
Gaind the level summit, and when Aurora
Ushers o'er the hills the car of day, all
Rang'd in order firm, and dread array of
War, we'll shout her such a welcome, as shall
Make Quebec's rocky base to tremble! and
Wake each Frenchman out of his lethargic
Dream of vain security!

SP.SPEAKER: Leonatus.
SP.L: This project suits my disposition well
Methinks I can already see both fronts
In battle join'd; and every soldier
Pressing onward to the goal of glory!
Now their white ensigns beaten down, are all
Bestain'd with Gallic gore, and wear a purple
Dye! [recollecting himself] the thought transported me.
But here upon my sword [drawing] I swear [kissing it]
I from
That field will ne'er return, till victory
Is ours, or I'm born off with bleeding marks
Of honour.—

SP.SPEAKER: Britannicus.
SP.L: And on my sword [drawing his sword]
I swear [kissing it] with heart resolv'd,
And resolution firm to struggle for
The palm of victory, and if we fail,
I'll not think life worth care, to save it by
A forc'd retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: First Caledonian Chief,
SP.STAGE: [drawing his sword.]
SP.L: By this good ade I swear [kissing hi sword] which never prov'd
Unfaithful to my arm, nor fail'd me in
The greatest need; I'll put it once more to
The noblest test, and thro' the thickest ranks
Of Gauls, will hew my way victorious,
And make it blaze a bright example to
My corps, or fall that day, to be enroll'd
In future annals, among the worthy
Warriors slain on Abraham's Height.

SP.SPEAKER: Second Caledonian Chief,
SP.STAGE: [drawing his sword]
SP.L: I kiss [kissing his sword] this burnish'd steel, in token of
My great reverence for a soldier's name;
And promise by my hope of future fame
In war, to make the foes of Britain feel
Its mortal weight; duty nerves my willing
Arm, and honour gives the blade an edge; with
This I'll strive to rouze my troops to action,
And at the head of my battalion rush
Towards Quebec, leauing to conquest: But
If retain'd at bay, by groves of bay'nets,
And show'rs of sot, we bear not down the thick
Obstructing ranks of Frenchmen, retreat we'll
Scorn, deal death for death; and make them (as at
Fontenoy) purchase mournful victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: [drawing his sword] Mine be the task to rati∣fy the whole:
I likewise swear [kissing his sword] upon my sword, I'll
For conquest in the face of danger;
If human resolution can effect
The same, vict'ry shall be ours: we'll ravish
Her my friends to morrow! for if she's shy,
And seems about to quit us, we'll summon
All our manly strength, and fortitude of
Soul, arrest her forward steps, and pluck her
Back again; at least we can do this, earn
Honourable deaths, and fall amidst a
Monumental pile of glory, which we
Ourselves whilst living rais'd around us! and
Sampson like, drag with us to the grave whoe
Cohorts of our foes!
For vanquish'd, I will never more return.
Moncalm! I come, arm'd with angry Britain's
Vengeance, to scourge European scalpers,
And Canadian savages, and stand
Thy rival in the fiercst shock of battle! Exeunt omnes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: MONTMORENCI, the FRENCH CAMP. MONTCALM and LEVI.

SP.SPEAKER: MONTCALM.
SP.L: I'VE just receiv'd intelligence, that all
The English army is embark'd in boats,
And one division is already swiftly
Row'd beyond Quebec; the rest by all their
Motions, seem inclin'd to follow them.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: Then doubtless they'll attempt to land so near
As possible;
Shou'd we not, Sir, endeavour to oppose
And repel them, or give them a baneful
Welcome?

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Of that I've taken care.—
I've order'd Monsieur Bougainville
To draw out two thousand from the camp, and
Watch their motions: He marches this way,
And will soon be here for orders.
SP.STAGE: French drums beat a march.
SP.L: He comes with hasty steps and pleasure in his looks.
SP.STAGE: Enter Bougainville, addressing himself to Montcalm.
SP.L: Sir, your orders are obey'd:
I've march'd two thousand from the camp, men well
Resolv'd and eaer to perorm the duty you impose.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: 'Tis well Sir;—
May they answer ou bst expectations.
Proceed you now, and lead these men to the
Banks of the river, and wait in ambush
For the landing of the British troops, and
Choose your posts as time and circumstances
Will permit, to the best advantage.
As they row up the river, be sure you
Upward march likewise; whene'er they stop, then
Halt; if they fall down the stream, retreat with
Them, that in ev'ry shpe (like their evil
Genius) you may keep pace with them; and on
Their debarkation, be ready boldly
To receive them, in a show'r of leaden
Vengeance, wing'd with flame.
Be not afraid Sir, but we'll receive them
As we ought; for tho' they land, cloth'd in all
The terrors their boasted dreadful triple
Union can assume, I doubt not but we
Shall bring back with us, a good account of
These few audcious Britons. Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: But mark me well, Sir, should they down∣ward bend
Their course, and row as if they meant to reach
Quebec, or Lvi's Point again, then
Dispatch me word immdiately, and with
Your main corps follow the messenger to
The camp, with all the speed you can.
SP.STAGE: Exit Bougainville bowing. French troops beat a ma.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: Think you, Sir, Monsieur de Bougaiville
Has troops enough with him, to repeal all
The British forces, should they attempt to land?

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: All things together weigh'd▪ I think he has▪
He and his corps hve often trod the ground,
And in the darkest night can measure out
Its distance well: No thought of amush can
Alarm them, they tread on friendly ground, and
Are you know sustain'd by savages, tran'd
Up to night adventures, and to lurkin fights:
These Britons ne'er saw the ground, but at a
Distant view; and when they land, will tread at
Each uncertain step a hostile shore, and
Must come on in dread of pitflls, breast works,
Entrenchments, batteries, and ambuscades;
And when they shall receive the fire from our
Two thousand, their own fears, and the horrors
Of the night (full of black uncertainty)
Will multiply them to ten thousand strong.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: From which I may presume you wou'd infer,
They'll soon retreat back to their boats, or fall
A daring sacrifice, by a brik fire,
Kept up by our troops and friendly Indians.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: I do infer no less:—
Yet policy suggests I shou'd not march
The main body thither, least they evade
Us, and in the night ing, make good
Their landing at Montmorenci, and seize
Upon our camp untenable by few.
You've not forgot the fierce attack they made
On all our troops, in their first bold attempt.
And this I have t' observe, shou'd Bougainville
Be put to rout by rage unparallel'd,
And their rough impetuous charge, they know
Each avenue and path, and safely can
Retreat, whilst we to sustain them march out
With all our force, oppose rage to rage, check
The furious ardor of their souls, and from
Their weary troops, ravish with ease th' infant
Victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.P: I'm satisfy'd, and cannot doubt success.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Let us to the camp repair, and put all
In order for an attack upon us,
Or an evacuation; these Britons
Are not to be despis'd: they surely are,
I fear, meditating some grand design.
The gath'ring storm must e'er long fall somewhere;
And on that dubious hour the Gallic
Honour, Canaia's well, our own bright fame,
Britannia's enterprize, and Wolfe's rising
Glory hangs.
Whene'er it falls, I'll face the low'ring storm,
Let death put on th' most tremendous form;
With Wolfe I'll grapple for the laurel crown,
Tho' mighty fate against my purpose frown:
Yet if I fall, in death, 'tis some relief,
Britons were foes I fought, and wond'rous Wolfe their Chief!
SP.STAGE: [A woody scene, as if on the top of a bill, or precipice; and as near to the scene as possibe, to make room for the more ample scene of the Height of Abraham soon After.]
[Colonel behind the scenes.]
SP.L: Advance briskly on them, my brave fellows!
Climb that precipice, and close with the enemy!

DIV3.STAGE: A discharge of small arms and a shout. Enter several French soldiers retreating before an English Councel, at the head of some ight infantry: As they run across the stage, scene draws, and discovers a larger view of the Height of Abraham.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: The HEIGHT of ABRAHAM: WOLFE, LEONATUS, and BRITANNICUS, at the head of the troops; they all shout.

SP.SPEAKER: WOLFE.
SP.L: At length we've gain'd an ample sooting on
This Height of Abraham (to which my soul
With ardent wish hath long aspir'd) and are
Advanc'd upon the glorious edge of battle.
I will not ask my gallant soldiers, if
You're ready; th' alcrity with which you
Have explor'd the gloomy winding of this
Ascent, and the brisk manner in which you
Clamber'd up, surmounting all obstacles,
Declare to me with greater certainty
Than words, you're ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Britannicus.
SP.L: Each low'ring brow declares the reso∣lutions
Of their hearts, and indicates th' heroic
Workings of their souls; in every face
I read a warm imptience for th' onset
As if they'd say, why stand we here in cool
Deliberation? Let us to closest
Fight advance, our foes may see us frown, and
Mark each litted arm descending with the
Mortal blow, that we may hew thro' the front
Of their battle, and trample down their rear.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonatus.
SP.L: Who falls this day, may well be deem'd great in
His death; and worthy of a British Patrio's name!
How much our absent and worthy friends of
Freedom will envy us each gloriou wound we feel!

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: Oh! wh a beaming blaze of victory,
Love and never dng fame, will crown each
Rch survivor' head! who helps this day to
Rout the num'rous French, and scourge their scalping
Friends, (those bands of human brutes,) back to their
Lurking, ns and native wilds again!
Now beat our drums, and sound each instrument
Of war, whilst we march onward to the field
Of fame. [Drums beat, instruments sound.]
SP.STAGE: Exeunt, beating a march.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Scene draws, and discovers MONTCALM sitting in his Tent.
Enter LEVI.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: Sir, there's a rumour in our camp, that all
Th' English troops are ranging on the Height of
Abraham, if so, we may soon expect them here.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: It cannot be!—wou'd they dare attempt it?
They cannot have eluded Bougainville's
Caution!—He has not inadvertantly
Let them pass; and surely all our out-guards,
And centinels, have not been wrapt in one
Fatal delusion, all conspiring to
Retad a timely notice of their landing.
Perhaps a desperate few have straggled
Thither, in order to amuse our troops,
ike an unexpected blow:
Draw out a small detachment from the camp
Agat them.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: Nay, had they ev'ry man they've brought against
Qebec on Abraham's freight, I shou'd esteem
It out the forlorn hope of Britain.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Let my orders be executed, and
Bring me word immediately how matters go. Exit Levi.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm solus.
SP.L: If all their troops are there, they'll gives us work
Enough his day to drive them thence, and prove,
I fear, a dear bought victory to France.
SP.STAGE: Re-enter LEVI, in more haste.
SP.L: Sir! I fear it will require our umost
Efforts to repel the storm which threatens
Us! There's scarce a man of all the English
Toops, but now treads Abraham's Height! with head long
Rage tey stumbled up the precpice! and
With Herculean fury, their bombardiers,
And sailors, dag up th' artilery, and
With their light arm'd infantry, in equal
Pace they roll the brazen thunder onward!
They have already taken possession
Of the forts which guarded the ascent, and
Turn'd the guns upon our flying parties,
Who as they mingle with our forces, in
The out lines of our camp, spread terror.
SP.STAGE: Montcalm rising, na crawing his sword.
SP.L: Then now 'tis time to rouze, and stir ourselves!
Let the crums beat to arms! and call forth all
The pow'r within our camp; we'll onward march
To meet them; and before our walls, in presence
Of our friends, shall both our battles close. Exit Levi.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm solus.
SP.L: These Britons will compel us to hazard
All on eual footing on the plain, or
Force us tamely to sit down entrech'd and,
See Quebec by them beleaguer'd; but e'er
They shall do that, death or victory, shall
Be mine.
This day the fates weigh Britain against Gaul;
Wolfe, thou must bleed, or flee, or I will nobly fall. Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: [The French drums beat to arms.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: [Scene draws, MONTCALM and a FRENCH Officer at the head of his troops; the French drums beating a march.]

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.P: Halt.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LEVI.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Are all our Indians dispos'd of to the
Best advantage?

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: They are, Sir;—
And as fierce tigers from their covert, eye
Th' approaching kids and couchant lick their chaps,
Anticipating the delicious banquet;
They in their close ambush lurk, with furious
Expectation viewing the British troops,
Waiting for the welcome signal to fall
Upon their broken rear, or else pick up
The scatter'd remnant of their flying forces.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Since they seem to like the chace so well, I
Hope we'll give them sport enough e'er long.
SP.STAGE: turning to the soldiers.
SP.L: Now my brave countrymen, remember you
Are to fight in the cause of Lewis, the
Well-beloved of his people; you fight
Likewise your country's battle; and I may
Add, many of you here fight for wives, and
Children, and possessions; and if any thing
Can wake your dormant rage, and kindle up
A flame of valour in your souls, all these
Considerations can.

SP.SPEAKER: French Off.
SP.L: Altho' their army's greatly thinn'd, and they
Can scarcely number full five thousand strong,
And we, (excluding all our savages,)
Can muster twice their tale, yet think not they
May be easily repell'd; altho' we
Have no room to doubt of victory, if
We behave like men of spirit, who have
Their country's good at heart, yet march into
The field forewarned thus, with courage firm,
Boldly prepar'd for the severest trial
Of your manhood, and meet resolutely.
Expecting th' impetuosity of their charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: If you'd acquit yourselves as soldiers shou'd,
Who wish their King and country well, and long
Have tued for an opportunity,
To slaunch your bleeding mother's wounds, and to
Retrieve her long lost honour; you must not
Think meanly of them, but call up all the man
Within your souls, and bravely blaze, absorb'd
In valour's fame!
Intrepidly resolv'd, and silful, are
Their leaders, and commanders; rough, fierce and
Veteran, are their soldiers; and in their
Defeat, great w'd be our fame!
Let us march to meet thm.

STAGE.HI: Exeunt. drums beating a march: Scene clse.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.STAGE: WOLFE, as the head of the troops; a march beating; and opposite, as from MONTCALM's camp, enter an

SP.SPEAKER: Officer,
SP.STAGE: addressing himself to WOLFE.
SP.L: Sir, I came from reconnting Montcalm's
Camp▪ where with all the haste they're masters of▪
They're arming, evacuating the treches.
And forming on the plain; they seem inclin'd
To save us the trouble of forcing their
Etrenchments, and in a few minutes we may
Expect them here. Wolfe, turning to the soldiers.
Now the completion of your wishes is
At hand! you no more shall pant for war, and
With impatience glow, chiding the tady
Hours which roll'd inactively away,
Nor shall you ask indignantly again,
When shall we meet and rush upon our foes?
And battle with them, bay'net to bay'net,
Sword to sword, front to front, and man to man?
SP.STAGE: They all shout, and several call out.
SP.L: Lead us on to glorious death▪ or victory!
To glorious death, or victory! lead us on!

DIV3.STAGE: An Officer advances from the rear.

SP.L: Is the artillery well advanc'd?
They have already gain'd the rear,
And t'wixt the flanks of diff'rent corps, they are
Avancig to the front with intrepid
, and ready to eject their mingled
Storm of led and iron, to deform the
of war.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: When they have gain'd the front, (pregnant with fate)
Let our fulminating engines bellow
Britannia' salutation to the French;
'Midst which we will advance, careering in
The thunder storm.
Are all the corps dispos'd of as I order'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.L: Col'nel owe, and his light infantry, are
Dran in a semicircle round our rear, and
Left flnk, and form an offensive moving
ulwark against th' incuions of such foes,
A may be luking in the adjacent coppie,
Where doubtless all their Indians sculk:
Ev'ry other officer, and corps, fill their
Stations in the field.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: Then we are ready for the onset:
Good Providence! beried us.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.L: Whilst taversing the field, from rank to rank,
I found a smpathetic resolution
Spread from man to man; each lader glowing
With an indignant noble emulation
For glory▪ (ith sparkling eyes, brimful of
Fierce delight, and steady countenance) strove
To animate his corps, who stood alert:
And when the drum began to beat, join'd with
The shill , when the brisk canos of the
Trmpets echo'd thro' the ranks, and the deep
Throed cannons roar'd a dread prelude to
The battle, their gen'rous souls ilated
With a warlike pide! then (ke Jo's war-horse)
They bid adiu to ear, and with genuine
Freeborn ardor, eager for close action.
Join'd in loud concert with the mrtial grand
Enliv'ning melody▪ sending rth ther
Woted cheering shout of exaltation!

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe
SP.L: [ to the soldiers.] In view, before us lies
the plenteous field
Of martial glory, in which this day we
Ae to reap, with honourable oil, a
Matchles harvest of renown: Now is the
Time to serve our country well, to spread the
our Sov'reign's name, and with a
flme rush into battle.
Let glory warm our emulating hearts,
Like men in Britain's cause, to play our parts:
' Moncalm now, let us defiance roar,
And fate's untrodden path resolv'd explore:
And when the dredu conflict is begun,
Let each remember he's a Briton's son;
Each recollct Great Britain's wholesme laws,
Let each reflect he fights in freedom's caus;
Then glowing with the thoughts, we'll cage our foes;
Lighten like Jove, and deal our rivin blws.

DIV3.STAGE: [Scene cses, drums beat a short march on bth sides then a point of war; a dischare of artilery and mal arms, a shout of battle, and Indians yelling: Scene draws and discovers General Wolfe wounded n the ; an Officer attending]

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: You bleed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.P: The ball graz'd my wrist.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Shall a Surgeon be call'd to dress the wond, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wolfe.
SP.L: Call no Surgeon to a woun o ght as this.
SP.STAGE: [Taking out his hankerchie, and wapping it round his wrist]
SP.L: We waste the precious moments! whi all are
Upon the wing to honour! See, where the
Anstruthers and Caledonians, with a
Mutual emulaton, ew thro' the thick
Obstructing ranks of Frenchmen; and as they
Lit their burnish'd steel, they fling a transient
Gleam of terror round!
And see, where every other corps with
Bayonets fix'd▪ to close engagement throngs!
Let us my friend among'em speed, and in
Their front rush foremost to their goal of glory!

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt, in haste.
[A shout of battle, Indians yelling.]
Scene draws. LEVI and a FRENCH OFFICER in disorder.

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: The battle will be irretrievably
st, without a sudden turn!
Gen'ral Montcalm, and others are wounded!
The wings give way! the main body is broke!

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.L: The Indians faintly squall their horrid yell
Of onset! and in their thick abushment
Riveted agape, they gazing stand as
Thunderstruck!

SP.SPEAKER: Levi.
SP.L: Heav'ns! that such a handful of men should work
So much confusion!
Run!
Rally the broken troops, and make them stand;
Whilst I head and spirit up the main corps,
'Till Bougainville's reinforcement arrives.

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt severally, in haste.
[Montcalm brought in by two, his thighs wrapp'd up and bloody.]

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: Each Englishman this day behaves, as if
He wore Medusa's head! with Gorgon frowns
They look some Frenchmen pale and stiff with horror!
Whilst with averted looks, others retreat
With a Mercurial speed!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Soldier.
SP.L: Where'er they face, our troops retreat;
Or else they pierce and hew a lane of caruage out.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d. Soldier.
SP.L: Our army dares as far as men can do:
But who can stand the charge of these
Impetuous Britons!
The day is thes! Quebec must fall!

SP.SPEAKER: Montcalm.
SP.L: And Canada is lost!—Alas my country▪
As the roaring thunder, on the rapid
Wings of keen lightn'ing, bursts resistless thro'
